s.text: Some--including, in recent days, the Republican nominee himself--are drumming up scandal in such a biased and hypocritical way that they risk sacrificing both their credibility and their dignity for the sake of a lost cause.
"I mean, this is a potential abuse of the American system on behalf of an Indonesian billionaire in a way we have never seen in American history."
It's hard to say whether this is really true of Bill Clinton.
"Here's how to succeed in obstructing justice," William Safire wrote in a recent column in the New York

In those instances, unlike in the Indonesian one, there is strong evidence of a quid pro quo, or at least mutual back-scratching.

Bill Bennett said a few days ago that a second Clinton term could produce "something like we went through in the Watergate era," adding, "I believe this administration is one of the most corrupt in recent American history."
Dole later changed his position and demanded that Clinton explicitly promise to rule out pardons if re-elected.
Dole later changed his position and demanded that Clinton explicitly promise to rule out pardons if re-elected.
Dole later changed his position and demanded that Clinton explicitly promise to rule out pardons if re-elected.
Of course, it would be nice if we lived in a country where the political parties were not allowed to take half-a-million-dollar contributions from anyone.
It's understandable, of course, that conservative frustration levels should be running high these days.
In the first presidential debate, Dole comically demanded that Clinton say "no comment" when asked about pardons, which is more or less precisely what Clinton has done.
In the first presidential debate, Dole comically demanded that Clinton say "no comment" when asked about pardons, which is more or less precisely what Clinton has done.

Dole's campaign manager, Scott Reed, used the same weaselly language when he issued a statement attacking the "administration's potentially criminal actions in squeezing money out of the Indonesian Lippo conglomerate," going on to ask the president, "Why have you used U.S. foreign policy in Indonesia as a fund-raising tool to help secure illegal campaign contributions from a foreigner?"
